body: Should fix #961, at least in its most likely incarnations. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1362)

comment_data.body: This changes the condition when `message_number == i->message_number`

comment_regular_data.body: Please add a short description how the workaround works to that commit.

* Saturday, 2020-01-11 at 18:09 +0000 - sudden6 <notifications@github.com>:

>Please add a short description how the workaround works to that commit.

Done. (Not so short, though)

> How so?
m - (m + 1) == -1 == UINT32_MAX (mod 2^{32}),
and UINT32_MAX > (1 << 31).
So both the new and the old condition are false in the case
message_number == i->message_number. Right?

You are right, I didn't calculate this correctly.

But what about this case:

```
message_number = 0;
i->message_number = UINT32_MAX;
// before
message_number > i->message_number // false
// now
message_number - (i->message_number + 1) <= (1 << 31)
0 - (UINT32_MAX + 1) <= (1 << 31)
// UINT32_MAX + 1 overflows to 0
0 - (0) <= (1<<31) // true
```

To fix that you would need to change the condition to:

```
((uint64_t)message_number) - (message_number2 + ((uint64_t)1)) <= (((uint64_t)1) << 31);
```
But then the case
```
message_number = 0;
i->message_number = UINT32_MAX;
``
is broken.

I think the correct behaviour depends on what this code is supposed to do.
GCC complains that you're shifting into the sign bit with `(1 << 31)`, it should be `(UINT32_C(1) << 31)` to fix that.

* Wednesday, 2020-01-22 at 12:06 -0800 - sudden6 <notifications@github.com>:

>But what about this case:
>
>message_number = 0;
>i->message_number = UINT32_MAX;

Yes, that's the point of this commit -- in this situation, 
message_number should be considered newer than i->message_number.

* Wednesday, 2020-01-22 at 20:08 +0000 - sudden6 <notifications@github.com>:

>GCC complains that you're shifting into the sign bit with `(1 << 31)`, 
>it should be `(UINT32_C(1) << 31)` to fix that.

Argh. Thanks. Should be fixed now.

> Yes, that's the point of this commit -- in this situation,
message_number should be considered newer than i->message_number.

Ok, then this makes sense.

Can you rebase on master? this should make the tsan test pass too.

commit.message:
workaround for message number saving (fixes #961)

Put a future message number into the save file.

Peers require the message numbers of messages we send to increase
monotonically. If we save the current message number, then send further
messages, then quit without saving (e.g. due to a crash), and then
resume from the old save data, then monotonicity will fail. This commit
works around this problem by introducing an offset when the current
message number, so that even in the above circumstance, as long as fewer
messages than the offset were sent between saving and reloading, the
sent message numbers will increase monotonically.

The choice of offset is a balance between wanting it to be large enough
that there is room for plenty of messages to be sent in the above
scenario, and wanting to avoid the following potential problem: if we
repeatedly save and reload without sending any further messages, then
the message number may increase so far that peers will interpret an
eventual message as being old. This is not conceivably a practical issue
for the 32bit lossless message numbers, but is a concern for the 16bit
lossy message numbers.

workaround for message number saving (fixes #961)

Put a future message number into the save file.

Peers require the message numbers of messages we send to increase
monotonically. If we save the current message number, then send further
messages, then quit without saving (e.g. due to a crash), and then
resume from the old save data, then monotonicity will fail. This commit
works around this problem by introducing an offset when the current
message number, so that even in the above circumstance, as long as fewer
messages than the offset were sent between saving and reloading, the
sent message numbers will increase monotonically.

The choice of offset is a balance between wanting it to be large enough
that there is room for plenty of messages to be sent in the above
scenario, and wanting to avoid the following potential problem: if we
repeatedly save and reload without sending any further messages, then
the message number may increase so far that peers will interpret an
eventual message as being old. This is not conceivably a practical issue
for the 32bit lossless message numbers, but is a concern for the 16bit
lossy message numbers.
